facts: First state to declare Christmas an official holiday (1836)
Rosa Parks sparked the Civil Rights Movement in Montgomery
Home of the U.S. Space & Rocket Center in Huntsville
The typewriter was invented in Alabama
Has more species of freshwater fish than any other state
Largest state by area - bigger than Texas, California, and Montana combined
Has more than 3 million lakes
Home to 17 of the 20 highest peaks in the U.S.
Only state capital (Juneau) with no roads connecting it to the rest of the state
The Northern Lights are visible 243 days a year in Fairbanks
Grand Canyon is one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World
Phoenix is the 5th largest city in the U.S.
Has more copper than any other state
Pluto was discovered at Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff (1930)
The London Bridge was moved to Lake Havasu City
Only place in North America where diamonds can be found (Crater of Diamonds State Park)
Hot Springs National Park attracts over 1 million visitors annually
Walmart was founded in Bentonville in 1962
Home to the only active diamond mine in the U.S.
State name comes from a French interpretation of a Sioux word meaning 'downstream place'
Most populous state and 5th largest economy in the world
Home to Hollywood, Silicon Valley, and the entertainment industry
Death Valley holds the record for hottest temperature in North America (134°F)
Has both the highest point (Mt. Whitney) and lowest point (Death Valley) in the lower 48
Produces nearly all of America's almonds, artichokes, dates, figs, kiwi, and walnuts
Has the highest mean elevation of any U.S. state (6,800 feet)
Home to 58 mountains over 14,000 feet (Fourteeners)
Mesa Verde has over 4,000 archaeological sites
The world's largest flat-top mountain is in Grand Mesa
Colorado River provides water for 40 million people in 7 states
First written constitution in history (Fundamental Orders, 1639)
Home to the first hamburger (Louis' Lunch, 1900) and first lollipop
Yale University, founded 1701, is one of America's oldest universities
The first nuclear submarine was built in Groton
Insurance capital of the world with many major insurers headquartered here
First state to ratify the U.S. Constitution (Dec 7, 1787)
Second smallest state, but home to more corporations than people
No sales tax makes it a popular shopping destination
Rehoboth Beach is known as 'The Nation's Summer Capital'
The log cabin was introduced to America in Delaware by Swedish settlers
Most popular vacation destination in the U.S.
No point in Florida is more than 60 miles from the ocean
St. Augustine is the oldest continuously occupied European settlement in the U.S. (1565)
The Everglades is the only place in the world where alligators and crocodiles coexist
Home to the most golf courses of any state
Largest state east of the Mississippi River
Coca-Cola was invented in Atlanta in 1886
Home to the world's busiest airport (Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta)
Produces more peanuts and pecans than any other state
The Girl Scouts were founded in Savannah in 1912

Hawaii.motto: The Life of the Land is Perpetuated in Righteousness
facts: Only state made entirely of islands (137 islands)
The only state that grows coffee commercially
Has its own time zone (Hawaiian Standard Time)
Most isolated population center on Earth - 2,390 miles from California
Kilauea is the world's most active volcano
Produces about one-third of all potatoes grown in the U.S.
Has more whitewater river miles than any other state
Craters of the Moon looks so much like the moon, astronauts trained there
Sun Valley was America's first destination ski resort (1936)
The deepest river gorge in North America is Hells Canyon
Chicago is the 3rd largest city in the U.S.
Home of Abraham Lincoln - his tomb, home, and presidential library are in Springfield
The first skyscraper was built in Chicago (1885)
Route 66 begins in Chicago
O'Hare Airport is one of the world's busiest
Home of the Indianapolis 500, the world's largest single-day sporting event
Santa Claus, Indiana receives over 500,000 letters every December
Produces more popcorn than any other state
Wabash was the first electrically-lit city in the world (1880)
The movie 'Hoosiers' was filmed here about Indiana high school basketball

Iowa.motto: Our Liberties We Prize and Our Rights We Will Maintain
facts: Leads the nation in corn and soybean production
Home of the Iowa State Fair, one of the oldest and largest in the U.S.
The Field of Dreams movie site is a popular tourist attraction
First state to legalize interracial marriage (1851)
Captain James T. Kirk (Star Trek) was 'born' in Riverside, Iowa
Geographic center of the 48 contiguous states is near Lebanon, Kansas
'The Wizard of Oz' is set in Kansas
Dodge City was the 'Cowboy Capital' during the Wild West era
World's largest ball of twine (over 5 million feet) is in Cawker City
Kansas produces enough wheat each year to bake 36 billion loaves of bread

Kentucky.motto: United We Stand, Divided We Fall
facts: Home of the Kentucky Derby, the longest continuously running sporting event in the U.S.
Produces 95% of the world's bourbon whiskey
Mammoth Cave is the world's longest known cave system (400+ miles)
Birthplace of Abraham Lincoln
'Happy Birthday to You' song was written by two Kentucky sisters
New Orleans is the birthplace of jazz music
Mardi Gras in New Orleans attracts over 1 million visitors annually
The Louisiana Purchase doubled the size of the United States
Home to America's largest swamp - the Atchafalaya Basin
Only state with parishes instead of counties
Easternmost state - the sun rises here first in the U.S.
90% of the nation's lobster supply comes from Maine
Has 3,478 miles of coastline
Acadia National Park is the first place to see the sunrise in the U.S.
L.L.Bean headquarters is open 24/7/365 in Freeport
The Star-Spangled Banner was written in Baltimore during the War of 1812
Home to the U.S. Naval Academy in Annapolis
Chesapeake Bay produces more blue crabs than anywhere else
First state to pass workers' compensation laws
Assateague Island is home to wild horses

Massachusetts.motto: By the Sword We Seek Peace, But Peace Only Under Liberty
facts: The Pilgrims landed at Plymouth Rock in 1620
Harvard (1636) is America's oldest university
Basketball and volleyball were both invented in Massachusetts
The Boston Tea Party sparked the American Revolution
Fig Newtons were named after Newton, Massachusetts

Michigan.motto: If You Seek a Pleasant Peninsula, Look About You
facts: Surrounded by four of the five Great Lakes
Detroit is the 'Motor City' - birthplace of the auto industry
Has more lighthouses than any other state (over 120)
No point in Michigan is more than 85 miles from a Great Lake
Mackinac Island doesn't allow cars - only horses and bikes
Actually has 11,842 lakes larger than 10 acres
Home to Mall of America, the largest mall in the U.S.
Minneapolis and St. Paul are called the 'Twin Cities'
The source of the Mississippi River is Lake Itasca
Has produced more hockey players than any other U.S. state
Birthplace of Elvis Presley in Tupelo
The blues music genre originated in the Mississippi Delta
Coca-Cola was first bottled in Vicksburg (1894)
Has the only cactus plantation in the world
The teddy bear was named after President Theodore Roosevelt after a hunting trip in Mississippi

Missouri.motto: Let the Welfare of the People Be the Supreme Law
facts: Gateway Arch in St. Louis is the tallest man-made monument in the U.S. (630 feet)
Kansas City has more fountains than any city except Rome
The ice cream cone was invented at the 1904 St. Louis World's Fair
Branson hosts more theater seats than Broadway
Harry S. Truman's home and library are in Independence
Fourth largest state but one of the least populated
Glacier National Park has over 700 miles of hiking trails
Home to the Little Bighorn Battlefield where Custer's Last Stand occurred
Has the largest grizzly bear population in the lower 48 states
Montana's name comes from the Spanish word for 'mountain'
Only state with a unicameral (one-house) legislature
Kool-Aid was invented in Hastings in 1927
Chimney Rock was a landmark on the Oregon Trail
Home to the world's largest indoor rainforest (Omaha's Henry Doorly Zoo)
Carhenge is a replica of England's Stonehenge made from vintage cars
Las Vegas is the 'Entertainment Capital of the World'
Driest state in the nation with less than 10 inches of rain per year
Home to Area 51, the secretive military base
Hoover Dam provides power to Nevada, Arizona, and California
More than 80% of the state is owned by the federal government
First state to declare independence from England (1776)
Holds the first presidential primary every four years
The Old Man of the Mountain was the state symbol until it collapsed in 2003
No state sales tax or income tax
Mount Washington has some of the world's worst weather
Most densely populated state in the U.S.
Atlantic City has the longest boardwalk in the world
Thomas Edison invented the light bulb in Menlo Park
First organized baseball game was played in Hoboken (1846)
Home to more diners than any other state
Santa Fe is the highest and oldest state capital (7,000 feet, founded 1610)
Roswell is famous for the alleged 1947 UFO incident
Home to Carlsbad Caverns, one of the world's largest cave chambers
White Sands National Park has the world's largest gypsum dune field
Smokey Bear was based on a real bear rescued from a New Mexico wildfire
New York City is the most populous city in the U.S. (8.3 million)
The Statue of Liberty was a gift from France in 1886
Niagara Falls is one of the most powerful waterfalls in the world
The first pizzeria in America opened in NYC in 1905
Central Park is larger than the principality of Monaco

North Carolina.motto: To Be Rather Than to Seem
facts: The Wright Brothers made the first powered flight at Kitty Hawk (1903)
Birthplace of Pepsi Cola in New Bern (1898)
The Biltmore Estate in Asheville is America's largest home
Research Triangle is one of the largest research parks in the world
First state university to open its doors (UNC, 1795)

North Dakota.motto: Liberty and Union, Now and Forever
facts: Geographic center of North America is near Rugby
Theodore Roosevelt National Park preserves the Badlands
The state has more wildlife refuges than any other state
Leads the nation in honey production
Has the tallest human-made structure in the Western Hemisphere (KVLY TV mast, 2,063 feet)

Ohio.motto: With God, All Things Are Possible
facts: Birthplace of aviation - the Wright Brothers were from Dayton
Eight U.S. Presidents were born in Ohio (more than any other state)
Rock and Roll Hall of Fame is in Cleveland
Cedar Point has some of the world's tallest and fastest roller coasters
The first professional baseball team was the Cincinnati Red Stockings (1869)
landmarks: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame

facts: Has more man-made lakes than any other state (over 200)
Oklahoma City is the horse show capital of the world
The shopping cart was invented in Oklahoma City (1936)
Route 66 runs through more miles of Oklahoma than any other state
Native American population is second highest in the nation

Oregon.motto: She Flies With Her Own Wings
facts: Crater Lake is the deepest lake in the U.S. (1,943 feet)
No sales tax makes Portland a popular shopping destination
The Oregon Trail brought over 400,000 settlers west in the 1800s
Home to the world's smallest park - Mill Ends Park (452 square inches)
Nike was founded in Oregon in 1964
The Declaration of Independence and Constitution were signed in Philadelphia
Hershey is the 'Chocolate Capital of the World'
The first computer was invented at the University of Pennsylvania (1946)
Punxsutawney Phil predicts the weather every Groundhog Day
Liberty Bell is one of the most iconic American symbols
Smallest state by area but has over 400 miles of coastline
The Flying Horse Carousel in Watch Hill is the oldest in America
Newport has more colonial buildings than any other city
The diner was invented in Providence
Rhode Island was the first of the 13 colonies to declare independence from Britain
First state to secede from the Union, starting the Civil War
Charleston is considered one of America's most beautiful and historic cities
Myrtle Beach attracts over 20 million visitors annually
The first tea farm in America is on Wadmalaw Island
South Carolina produces more peaches than Georgia
Mount Rushmore features the faces of four U.S. Presidents carved into granite
Crazy Horse Memorial, when completed, will be the world's largest sculpture
Badlands National Park has some of Earth's richest fossil beds
Sue, the largest and most complete T-Rex skeleton, was found here
The geographic center of the United States is near Belle Fourche
Nashville is the 'Country Music Capital of the World'
Memphis is the birthplace of blues, soul, and rock n' roll
Great Smoky Mountains is the most visited national park in the U.S.
Jack Daniel's whiskey has been made in Lynchburg since 1866
Graceland, Elvis Presley's home, attracts 600,000 visitors annually
Second largest state in area and population
Was an independent nation from 1836-1845 (Republic of Texas)
The Alamo in San Antonio is the most visited site in Texas
Six Flags Over Texas refers to the six nations that have ruled Texas
Austin is the 'Live Music Capital of the World' with over 250 venues
Home to the 'Mighty Five' national parks (Zion, Bryce, Arches, Capitol Reef, Canyonlands)
Has the greatest snow on Earth for skiing
Salt Lake is the headquarters of the Mormon Church
Great Salt Lake is saltier than the ocean
Rainbow Bridge is the world's largest natural bridge
Produces more maple syrup than any other state
Montpelier is the smallest state capital by population
Ben & Jerry's Ice Cream was founded in Burlington
Covered bridges are a Vermont icon with over 100 still standing
The Long Trail is America's oldest long-distance hiking trail
Eight U.S. Presidents were born in Virginia (most of any state)
Jamestown (1607) was the first permanent English settlement in America
Pentagon is the world's largest office building
Virginia Beach is the most populous city in Virginia
More Civil War battles were fought here than any other state
Seattle is home to Microsoft, Amazon, Boeing, and Starbucks
Mount Rainier is the most glaciated peak in the lower 48 states
The San Juan Islands are a popular whale-watching destination
Produces more apples, cherries, and pears than any other state
Olympic National Park has temperate rainforests, mountains, and coastline
Only state to form by seceding from a Confederate state during the Civil War
New River is actually one of the oldest rivers in the world
More than 75% of the state is covered in forests
Harper's Ferry is where John Brown's raid occurred in 1859
Home to the National Radio Astronomy Observatory
Produces more cheese than any other state (over 600 varieties)
Milwaukee is the 'Beer Capital' and home to major breweries
The Republican Party was founded in Ripon in 1854
The Ice Age National Scenic Trail runs 1,200 miles through the state
The Ringling Brothers Circus was founded in Baraboo
Least populous state in the U.S.
First state to grant women the right to vote (1869)
Yellowstone was the world's first national park (1872)
Devils Tower was America's first national monument
Grand Teton has some of the most dramatic mountain scenery in America
